description:
A course designed to allow the students to discover their own talents in at least two forms from a list that includes fiction, poetry, journalistic writing, creative nonfiction writing, and memoir. Though emphasis is on practice, classroom work includes discussion of theory as well as readings in published works. Frequent writing assignments. Reading lists vary with each section. See the English Department's website at www.english.upenn.edu for a description of the current offerings.

name: CREATIVE WRITING: CREAT. WRITE: FICT/POET

values.comments:
In this workshop-style class, the relationship between fact and writing is explored, in both traditional and non-traditional poetic and non-fiction forms. The class discusses the pieces -- who is the writer representing, to whom are they speaking, what are facts are they highlighting -- in an effort to understand better how to best present their own writing. 

Students enjoyed this “fantastic” course’s “fun and liberating classroom vibe.” Though the course was not considered especially challenging, many students found that their writing improved over the span of the semester.

Students found Professor Aptowicz “enthusiastic and knowledgeable.” They praised her ability to think up “unusually creative” assignments and to give excellent feedback. Students were pleased with Professor Aptowicz’ teaching style, calling her “inspiring” overall.

Both majors and non-majors found this course interesting. A non-major recalled feeling “extremely welcomed” in the classroom environment and was pleased to be graded on effort more heavily than ability. Aside from the final portfolio, students were expected to generate a high volume of poetry and short non-fiction inspired by the works examined in class. Based on fewer than 8 comments.
